Hands-on is Key: The best way to learn notebooks and Git integration is by actively using them.
Best Practices: Think about how these features support best practices in data engineering (e.g., modular code, version control, reusability).



Day 9: Data Ingestion with Auto Loader & COPY INTO (4-5 hours)
[DBDEPC] Data Ingestion with Auto Loader & COPY INTO

Topic Breakdown:

Data Ingestion Overview: Understand common ingestion patterns into a Lakehouse.
Auto Loader: Learn about this powerful feature for incrementally and efficiently processing new data files as they arrive in cloud storage. Understand file notification mode vs. directory listing mode.
COPY INTO: A declarative SQL command for idempotent (safe to re-run) and efficient loading of data into Delta Lake tables from various file formats. When to choose COPY INTO vs. Auto Loader.
Supported Formats and Sources: Parquet, CSV, JSON, Avro, ORC from S3, ADLS, GCS.

Why this is best: Comprehensive guide to Auto Loader, covering concepts, configuration, and examples.


Official Docs (COPY INTO): COPY INTO

Link: https://docs.databricks.com/en/sql/language-manual/copy-into.html
Why this is best: The official reference for the COPY INTO SQL command, including syntax and use cases.


YouTube (Tutorial): Ingest files into Delta Lake with Auto Loader | Databricks

Link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EqNf3_x8I0w
Why this is good: An official Databricks video demonstrating the practical use of Auto Loader.




AI Tool & Tips:

ChatGPT/Gemini: Ask: "Compare Auto Loader and COPY INTO for data ingestion in Databricks, providing a scenario where each would be preferred." or "Write a PySpark Auto Loader code snippet to incrementally load CSV files from an S3 bucket into a Delta table."
Databricks Community Edition: Try setting up a small-scale Auto Loader stream (e.g., using a local folder or a public S3 bucket with sample data). Experiment with the COPY INTO command in a SQL cell.


Study Tips:

Idempotency: Understand why COPY INTO is idempotent and how Auto Loader achieves "exactly-once" processing.
Use Cases: Think about different data ingestion scenarios and which method (Auto Loader, COPY INTO, or traditional batch loads) would be most suitable for each.



Day 10: Structured Streaming Fundamentals (4-5 hours)

Basic Transformations: Applying common DataFrame transformations (e.g., select, filter, withColumn) to streaming data.
Watermarking (Conceptual): Briefly introduce watermarking for handling late-arriving data in event-time processing.
Checkpoints: Understand the role of checkpoints for fault tolerance and recovery in streaming applications.

Day 11: Medallion Architecture & Data Quality (4-5 hours)
[DBDEPC] Medallion Architecture & Data Quality

Day 14: Performance Optimization (Spark & Delta) (4-5 hours)
[DBDEPC] Performance Optimization (Spark & Delta)

Topic Breakdown:

Common Bottlenecks: Identify typical performance issues in Spark (shuffling, data skew, small files, memory issues).
Spark Optimizations:

Caching/Persisting: When and how to cache DataFrames or RDDs to reuse computed results.
Broadcast Joins: Optimizing joins when one DataFrame is small.
Adaptive Query Execution (AQE - Conceptual): Briefly mention how Spark automatically optimizes query execution.


Delta Lake Optimizations:

Compaction (OPTIMIZE): Understand the small file problem and how OPTIMIZE command helps consolidate small files into larger ones.
Z-Ordering: A technique to colocate related information in the same set of files, improving query performance.
Data Skipping: How Delta Lake leverages statistics to skip irrelevant data files.




Resource:

Official Docs (Optimization Overview): Optimization recommendations for Databricks

Link: https://docs.databricks.com/en/optimizations/index.html
Why this is best: A central hub for Databricks optimization techniques.


Official Docs (Delta Performance): Tune Delta Lake performance

Link: https://docs.databricks.com/en/delta/tune-performance.html
Why this is best: Specific recommendations for optimizing Delta Lake tables.


YouTube (Conceptual/Practical): Apache Spark Performance Tuning Explained!

Link: https://www.google.com/search?q=https://www.youtube.com/watch%3Fv%3Dyour_chosen_spark_sql_tuning_video
Why this is good: This video (from Data Engineering Central) covers key Spark performance tuning concepts and practical tips.




AI Tool & Tips:

ChatGPT/Gemini: Ask: "What is the 'small file problem' in data lakes, and how does the Delta Lake OPTIMIZE command help resolve it?" or "Explain the concept of data shuffling in Spark and how it can impact performance."
Databricks Community Edition: If possible, try running an OPTIMIZE command on a small Delta table you've created. Experiment with cache() on a DataFrame and observe its impact.


Study Tips:

Profiling: Understand that optimization often starts with identifying bottlenecks through monitoring Spark UI or query profiles.
Iterative Process: Performance tuning is rarely a one-time fix; it's an iterative process of identifying, optimizing, and re-evaluating.

Databricks Architecture Deep Dive: Explore the logical and physical separation of the Control Plane (managing workspaces, notebooks, jobs) and the Data Plane (where your actual data processing happens on cloud compute). Understand how Databricks leverages cloud infrastructure (AWS, Azure, GCP).
Key Features & Value Proposition: Focus on data reliability, security, governance (at a high level), and real-time analytics capabilities that the platform offers.

Phase 1: Databricks Foundations
This phase provides a solid foundation in Databricks and its key components.

Week 1: Core Concepts
Day 3: Databricks Overview & Architecture (4-5 hours)
[DBDEPC] Databricks Overview & Architecture

Topic Breakdown:

Databricks Lakehouse Platform: Understand the concept of a Lakehouse and how Databricks unifies data warehousing and data science. Learn why it's considered the next generation of data architectures.
Databricks Architecture Deep Dive: Explore the logical and physical separation of the Control Plane (managing workspaces, notebooks, jobs) and the Data Plane (where your actual data processing happens on cloud compute). Understand how Databricks leverages cloud infrastructure (AWS, Azure, GCP).
Key Features & Value Proposition: Focus on data reliability, security, governance (at a high level), and real-time analytics capabilities that the platform offers.


Resource:

Official Docs (Core): Databricks Lakehouse Platform Overview

Link: https://docs.databricks.com/en/introduction/index.html
Why this is best: This is the foundational documentation directly from Databricks. It provides the most accurate and up-to-date overview of the platform's architecture and vision. Focus on the "Platform architecture" and "Lakehouse Platform" sections.


YouTube (Visual Explanation): Databricks Lakehouse Platform Explained in 7 Minutes

Link: https://www.google.com/search?q=https://www.youtube.com/watch%3Fv%3DyW6W4bF9G2o
Why this is good: A concise, visual explanation from Databricks' official YouTube channel. Excellent for a quick conceptual grasp and to supplement the official docs.


Official Blog (Strategic): What is a Lakehouse?

Link: https://www.databricks.com/glossary/data-lakehouse
Why this is best: Provides a clear definition and strategic importance of the Lakehouse architecture, which is central to Databricks.




AI Tool & Tips:

ChatGPT/Gemini: Ask: "Explain the difference between a traditional data warehouse, a data lake, and a data lakehouse architecture." or "Describe a scenario where Databricks' unified platform significantly benefits a data engineering team."
NotebookLM: Upload parts of the Databricks architecture documentation. Ask: "Summarize the key responsibilities of the Databricks control plane." or "How does Databricks ensure data security within the data plane?"


Study Tips:

Visualize: Draw a simple diagram of the Databricks architecture, labeling the Control Plane, Data Plane, and their interaction with cloud storage and compute.
Conceptual Understanding: Don't get bogged down in too much technical detail initially. Focus on the why behind the Lakehouse concept and Databricks' architectural choices.



Day 4: Apache Spark Fundamentals (4-5 hours)
[DBDEPC] Apache Spark Fundamentals

Topic Breakdown:

Spark Core Concepts: Understand Spark's distributed processing model, including drivers, executors, tasks, jobs, stages, and shuffling.
Resilient Distributed Datasets (RDDs): Grasp the concept of RDDs as Spark's fundamental data abstraction, and its immutability and fault tolerance.
DataFrames and Spark SQL: Learn to work with structured data using DataFrames (Python, Scala, SQL APIs) as the preferred abstraction for most modern Spark applications. Understand their advantages over RDDs for structured data.
Transformations and Actions: Distinguish between transformations (lazy operations that build a logical plan) and actions (which trigger the execution of the plan and return results).


Resource:

Free Course (Practical): Apache Spark Fundamentals with PySpark - DataCamp Tutorial

Link: https://www.datacamp.com/tutorial/apache-spark-tutorial
Why this is best: This is a well-structured, interactive tutorial that provides hands-on code examples in PySpark, which is highly relevant for data engineering. It covers SparkSession, DataFrames, transformations, and actions.


Official Docs (Reference): Apache Spark Programming Guide - RDDs and DataFrames

Link: https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/rdd-programming-guide.html (for RDDs) and https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/sql-programming-guide.html (for DataFrames/Spark SQL)
Why this is best: The authoritative source for Spark's core concepts. Refer to these sections after going through tutorials for deeper understanding.


YouTube (Visual Explanation): Apache Spark Architecture Explained!

Link: https://www.google.com/search?q=https://www.youtube.com/watch%3Fv%3Dyour_chosen_scd2_pyspark_delta_video
Why this is good: This video (from Data Engineering Central) provides a clear and well-explained overview of Spark's architecture, which is crucial for understanding how Spark processes data distributively.




AI Tool & Tips:

ChatGPT/Gemini: Ask: "Explain the concept of lazy evaluation in Apache Spark and why it's beneficial." or "Provide a PySpark example that demonstrates a transformation followed by an action on a DataFrame."
Code Interpreter/Databricks Community Edition: If you have access (even a free trial), try running simple PySpark code to create DataFrames, perform transformations (e.g., filter, select), and then an action (e.g., show, count).


Study Tips:

Interactive Learning: The DataCamp tutorial's hands-on exercises are key. Run the code and see the results.
Conceptual Distinction: Ensure you clearly understand the difference between transformations (which don't trigger computation) and actions (which do). This is a common point of confusion.
Execution Flow: Try to trace the execution flow of a simple Spark job: code -> driver -> cluster manager -> executors.



Day 5: Delta Lake Fundamentals (4-5 hours)
[DBDEPC] Delta Lake Fundamentals

Topic Breakdown:

Introduction to Delta Lake: Understand its role as an open-source storage layer that brings ACID properties (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability) and other data warehousing capabilities to data lakes.
Delta Lake Architecture: Learn about the foundational transaction log (or Delta Log) and how it enables reliability, versioning, and concurrent operations.
Basic Delta Lake Operations (using PySpark/SQL): Learn to create Delta tables, read data, append data, and perform basic UPDATE, DELETE, and MERGE (UPSERT) operations.


Resource:

Official Docs (Core): Delta Lake Documentation - Getting Started

Link: https://docs.delta.io/latest/delta-getting-started.html
Why this is best: The official source for Delta Lake. Focus on the "Key Concepts" and "Quickstart" sections to get a solid grasp of its fundamentals and initial syntax.


YouTube (Conceptual): Delta Lake Explained Clearly in 10 Minutes

Link: https://www.google.com/search?q=https://www.youtube.com/watch%3Fv%3Dyour_chosen_spark_sql_tuning_video
Why this is good: This video (from Data Engineering Central) offers a concise and easy-to-understand explanation of Delta Lake's core benefits and architecture.


Tutorial (Hands-on PySpark): Getting Started with Delta Lake - Databricks Tutorial

Link: https://docs.databricks.com/en/delta/delta-start.html
Why this is best: Provides practical PySpark examples for creating and manipulating Delta tables directly within a Databricks context (even if you're using Community Edition).




AI Tool & Tips:

ChatGPT/Gemini: Ask: "What problem does Delta Lake solve for data lakes?" or "Explain the ACID properties in the context of Delta Lake with a simple example for each."
Code Interpreter/Databricks Community Edition: Practice running the PySpark/SQL examples from the tutorials. Try creating a Delta table, inserting data, updating a row, and then deleting another. Observe how the data changes.


Study Tips:

Transaction Log: Understand that the transaction log is the heart of Delta Lake's reliability. Visualize how it records changes.
ACID Properties: For each property (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability), think of a real-world data scenario where it would prevent a problem.



Day 6: Delta Lake Advanced Features (4-5 hours)
[DBDEPC] Delta Lake Advanced Features: Time Travel & Schema Evolution

Topic Breakdown:

Time Travel (Data Versioning): Learn how Delta Lake maintains historical versions of your data. Understand how to query data AS OF VERSION or TIMESTAMP for auditing, rollbacks, and reproducible experiments.
Schema Enforcement: Understand how Delta Lake prevents bad data from corrupting your table by enforcing the schema.
Schema Evolution: Learn how to gracefully handle changes to your data schema (e.g., adding new columns, reordering columns) without breaking existing pipelines. Understand the mergeSchema option.
Table Optimization (Basic): Brief introduction to Z-Ordering and OPTIMIZE command for performance.


Resource:

Official Docs (Time Travel): Query an older version of a table (Time Travel) - Delta Lake

Link: https://docs.delta.io/latest/delta-debugging.html#query-an-older-version-of-a-table-time-travel
Why this is best: Direct from Delta Lake docs, covers the syntax and use cases for Time Travel.


Official Docs (Schema): Schema enforcement and evolution - Delta Lake

Link: https://docs.delta.io/latest/delta-schema.html
Why this is best: Comprehensive guide to schema enforcement and evolution, including the mergeSchema option.


YouTube (Deep Dive): Delta Lake: Time Travel, Schema Evolution, and More!

Link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=APc2tX_T728
Why this is good: This video provides a more in-depth look at these advanced features with practical demonstrations.




AI Tool & Tips:

ChatGPT/Gemini: Ask: "How can Delta Lake's Time Travel feature help in debugging a data quality issue that occurred last week?" or "Explain the difference between schema enforcement and schema evolution in Delta Lake, and when you would use each."
Code Interpreter/Databricks Community Edition: Create a Delta table. Insert some data. Then insert more data with a new column (using mergeSchema). Then use Time Travel to query the table before and after the schema change.


Study Tips:

Use Cases: Think of real-world scenarios where Time Travel (auditing, bug fixes) and Schema Evolution (evolving data sources) would be invaluable.
Hands-on is Crucial: These features are best understood by actually trying them out in a Spark/Databricks environment.



Day 7: Databricks Workflows & Basic Tools (4-5 hours)
[DBDEPC] Databricks Workflows, CLI & REST API

Topic Breakdown:

Databricks Workflows (Jobs): Learn how to schedule and orchestrate multi-task data pipelines within Databricks. Understand job definitions, task dependencies, retries, and monitoring.
Databricks CLI (Command Line Interface): How to interact with Databricks resources (clusters, jobs, notebooks) from your local terminal. Essential for scripting and automation.
Databricks REST API (Introduction): Understand the power of the REST API for programmatic control over your Databricks workspace, enabling integration with external tools or custom applications.


Resource:

Official Docs (Workflows): What are Databricks Workflows?

Link: https://docs.databricks.com/en/workflows/index.html
Why this is best: The official source for Databricks Workflows, covering creation, management, and monitoring of jobs.


Official Docs (CLI): Databricks CLI

Link: https://docs.databricks.com/en/dev-tools/cli/index.html
Why this is best: Provides installation instructions and command references for programmatic interaction with Databricks.


Official Docs (REST API): Databricks REST API reference

Link: https://docs.databricks.com/api/latest/
Why this is best: The comprehensive reference for all Databricks API endpoints. Focus on understanding the categories of APIs (e.g., Clusters API, Jobs API, Workspace API).


YouTube (Workflows Tutorial): Orchestrate Data Pipelines with Databricks Workflows

Link: https://www.google.com/search?q=https://www.youtube.com/watch%3Fv%3DAPc2tX_T728
Why this is good: A visual walk-through of creating and managing Databricks Workflows.




AI Tool & Tips:

ChatGPT/Gemini: Ask: "Generate a YAML configuration for a simple Databricks Workflow that runs two sequential notebook tasks." or "How can I use the Databricks CLI to check the status of all running jobs in my workspace?"
Databricks Workspace: Practice creating a simple Databricks Job/Workflow directly in the UI. Try setting up basic dependencies and notifications.


Study Tips:

Automation Mindset: Understand that Workflows, CLI, and API are essential for moving from ad-hoc notebook execution to robust, automated production pipelines.
Practical Application: If you have Databricks Community Edition, try installing the CLI and running a few basic commands to list workspaces or clusters.

Phase 0: Immediate Impact & Quick Wins
This initial phase is designed to give you immediate practical skills in AI (specifically Prompt Engineering) and introduce the core concepts of Databricks and the Lakehouse, setting the stage for deeper dives.

Week 1: Immediate Impact & Databricks Foundations
Day 1: AI Essentials & Prompt Engineering Fundamentals (4-5 hours)
AI Essentials & Prompt Engineering Fundamentals

Topic Breakdown:

Understanding the AI Landscape: Briefly touch upon the differences and relationships between Artificial Intelligence (AI), Machine Learning (ML), Deep Learning (DL), and Generative AI (GenAI). Focus on Large Language Models (LLMs) as the core of modern GenAI.
What is Prompt Engineering? Learn its definition, why it's crucial for interacting with LLMs, and its role in maximizing AI utility.
Core Principles of Effective Prompting:

Clarity & Specificity: How to write unambiguous prompts.
Context: Providing relevant background information.
Role-Playing: Assigning a persona to the AI.
Iteration: The process of refining prompts.
Output Format: Requesting specific output structures (e.g., JSON, bullet points).




Resource:

Free Course (Highly Recommended): Google Cloud Skills Boost - Introduction to Generative AI Learning Path

Link: https://www.cloudskillsboost.google/journeys/118
Why this is best: This is an official Google learning path, highly reputable, frequently updated, and offers a structured, hands-on introduction to GenAI and foundational prompt engineering concepts. It includes multiple courses and labs.
Focus on: Start with the first module "Introduction to Generative AI" within this path.


Official Guide (Reference): Prompt Engineering Guide

Link: https://www.promptingguide.ai/
Why this is best: A comprehensive, open-source guide maintained by the community. Excellent for looking up specific techniques and concepts. Focus on the "Basic Prompting" section.


YouTube Video (Supplemental): What is Prompt Engineering? Explained in 100 Seconds

Link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EqNf3_x8I0w
Why this is good: A quick, high-level overview to get a foundational understanding before diving into deeper content. From a reputable channel (Fireship).




AI Tool & Tips:

ChatGPT / Gemini / Claude: Immediately put concepts into practice. Open a chat interface.
Experimentation:

Start with simple prompts: "Explain the difference between AI and ML."
Then try adding specificity: "Explain the difference between AI and ML for a 5th grader."
Experiment with output formats: "List 5 benefits of cloud computing in bullet points."
Try assigning roles: "Act as a senior data engineer. Explain the Medallion architecture in data lakes."




Study Tips:

Interactive Learning: The Google course emphasizes hands-on labs. Do them! This is crucial for internalizing concepts.
Vocabulary: Familiarize yourself with terms like LLM, Token, Hallucination, Temperature, etc.
"Think out loud" in prompts: When you're stuck, ask the AI to "think step by step" or "explain your reasoning."



Day 2: Practical Prompt Engineering & Immediate Application (4-5 hours)
Practical Prompt Engineering & Immediate Application

Topic Breakdown:

Advanced Prompting Techniques:

Few-shot Prompting: Providing examples to guide the model.
Chain-of-Thought (CoT) Prompting: Encouraging step-by-step reasoning.
Persona Prompting: Mastering consistent role adoption.
Zero-shot CoT/Self-Consistency: Advanced reasoning without examples.


Real-world Applications for Data Professionals:

Code Generation & Explanation: Generating Python/SQL snippets, explaining complex code.
Data Summarization & Analysis: Summarizing reports, extracting insights from text.
Documentation & Learning: Creating quick explanations, generating study guides.
Troubleshooting: Getting assistance with error messages.


Ethical Considerations in Prompting: Bias, privacy, misuse, and responsible AI practices.


Resource:

Free Course (Highly Recommended): DeepLearning.AI - Prompt Engineering for Developers

Link: https://www.deeplearning.ai/courses/prompt-engineering-for-developers/
Why this is best: Taught by Isa Fulford (OpenAI) and Andrew Ng (DeepLearning.AI), this course is incredibly practical and focuses on best practices for developers. It includes hands-on labs with Python. Check for free enrollment options or audit tracks.
Focus on: All modules, especially "Guidelines for Prompting," "Iterative Prompt Development," and "Summarizing/Inferring/Transforming/Expanding."


YouTube Video (Practical Examples): Prompt Engineering Tutorial - Master OpenAI's API

Link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F0f-k13y0L4
Why this is good: From Data Engineering Central, a reputable channel. This video focuses on practical applications of prompt engineering, including code generation and interacting with APIs, which is highly relevant for data professionals.




AI Tool & Tips:

Gemini/ChatGPT/Claude (continued): Use these to practice all the advanced techniques.
Iterative Refinement: Don't expect the perfect prompt on the first try. Start broad, then add constraints, examples, or personas.
Code Generation: Ask the AI to write a Python function for a specific data manipulation task. Then ask it to explain its own code.
Data Summarization: Provide a few paragraphs of text and ask the AI to summarize it for a specific audience (e.g., "Summarize this article for a busy executive").


Study Tips:

Active Practice: The core of prompt engineering is doing. Spend more time in the AI chat interface experimenting than just reading.
Document Prompts: Keep a small notebook or a Gist/Obsidian vault where you store effective prompts that yield good results for various tasks.
Ethical Check: Before using AI-generated content, always critically evaluate it for bias, factual accuracy, and appropriateness.

Phase 0: Immediate Impact & Quick Wins
This initial phase is designed to quickly onboard you to essential AI concepts, prompt engineering, and fundamental Databricks features. The goal is to equip you with immediately applicable skills that can yield quick wins and build confidence.

Week 1: Immediate Impact & Databricks Foundations
Day 1: AI Essentials & Prompt Engineering Basics (4-5 hours)
AI Essentials & Prompt Engineering Basics

Topic:

Introduction to AI/ML/GenAI: Understanding the differences between Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, and Generative AI. Grasping the core capabilities and limitations of each.
Large Language Models (LLMs): A high-level overview of what LLMs are, how they work fundamentally (training on vast text data), and their emergent abilities.
Prompt Engineering Fundamentals: Learning the art and science of crafting effective prompts to get desired outputs from LLMs. Key principles include clarity, specificity, persona, format, and iterative refinement.
Ethical Considerations in AI: Basic awareness of biases, fairness, privacy, and responsible AI usage.


Resource:

Free Course (Conceptual): Google AI for Everyone (Coursera, audit option available for free access). Focus on Week 1-2 for high-level AI/ML/GenAI concepts.
Free Course (Practical): Prompt Engineering for Developers (DeepLearning.AI - short, free, hands-on, highly recommended). Focus on the core principles and examples.
Article (LLMs): What are Large Language Models (LLMs)? (IBM Blog - concise explanation).
Article (Prompt Eng.): Introduction to Prompt Engineering (Prompting Guide - excellent, comprehensive resource).


AI Tool & Tips:

ChatGPT / Gemini: Use these tools directly to practice prompt engineering.

Tip 1: Iterative Refinement: Ask the LLM to act as a "junior data engineer" and explain a concept. Then, refine your prompt: "Explain it to a beginner, simplify jargon," "Provide a code example," "List 3 pros and 3 cons."
Tip 2: Persona-Based Prompting: Experiment with prompts like: "Act as an experienced data architect. Design a data pipeline for X." or "You are a senior data scientist. Explain the importance of data quality for ML models."
Tip 3: Output Formatting: Request specific output formats, e.g., "Summarize this article as a bulleted list," or "Provide a Python function including docstrings and type hints."




Study Tips:

No Code Yet: Focus on understanding the concepts and the language of AI. Don't worry about coding today.
Hands-on Prompting: The most important part of today is actively experimenting with ChatGPT/Gemini. The DeepLearning.AI course is hands-on and will guide you.
Journal Prompts: Keep a simple text file or notebook where you note down successful prompts and the reasoning behind why they worked. This builds your "prompt library."



Day 2: Practical Prompt Engineering & Immediate Application (4-5 hours)
Practical Prompt Engineering & Immediate Application

Topic:

Advanced Prompt Techniques: Exploring few-shot prompting, chain-of-thought prompting, role-playing, and tool-use (where applicable).
Using LLMs for Learning: Leveraging LLMs as a personal tutor for understanding complex concepts, debugging, and code generation (with caution).
LLMs for Productivity: Applying prompt engineering to automate simple tasks, generate ideas, summarize long documents, or draft communications relevant to data engineering.
Setting up GitHub Gist: Creating your public GitHub Gist to document your learning journey and make it shareable.


Resource:

Free Course (Cont.): Prompt Engineering for Developers (DeepLearning.AI). Continue with modules on advanced techniques and applications.
Article (Examples): 10 Prompt Engineering Techniques for LLMs (AssemblyAI Blog - good practical examples).
Setup Guide: How to Create a GitHub Gist (Search for simple guides, e.g., "how to create a github gist markdown").


AI Tool & Tips:

ChatGPT / Gemini: Your primary tools for practice.

Tip 1: Debugging Buddy: Copy-paste a small code snippet (e.g., Python, SQL) with an error and ask: "This code is giving an error: [paste error message]. What's wrong and how can I fix it?" or "Explain why this code is inefficient and suggest improvements."
Tip 2: Concept Clarification: Ask: "Explain the difference between a JOIN and a UNION in SQL, providing a simple example for each." or "Break down the concept of 'data partitioning' into simpler terms."
Tip 3: Content Summarization/Expansion: "Summarize this long article into 5 key bullet points." or "Expand on this idea of data lineage for a presentation slide."




Study Tips:

Hands-on Gist Creation: Follow a guide to create your GitHub Gist today. This is where you'll be documenting your progress.
Document Everything: Start documenting your learning from Day 1 in your Gist. Include key takeaways, prompt examples, and any small code snippets or commands you found useful.
Critical Thinking: Always critically evaluate AI-generated code or explanations. Don't just copy-paste; understand why it works (or doesn't). AI is a powerful assistant, not a replacement for understanding.

Phase 1: AI-Focused Databricks Deep Dive & Data Engineering Excellence

Week 1 (cont.): Databricks Foundations
Day 3: Databricks Architecture & Apache Spark Fundamentals (3-4 hours)
[DBDEPC] Databricks Architecture & Apache Spark Fundamentals

Topic: Databricks Lakehouse Platform architecture (Control Plane, Data Plane, Workspace). Apache Spark architecture (Driver, Executors, Jobs, Stages, Tasks, RDDs, DataFrames, Datasets).
Resource:

Official Docs: Databricks Lakehouse Platform Architecture
Official Docs: Apache Spark Architecture Overview
Video: [suspicious link removed] (Search for a clear, concise explanation)


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload architectural diagrams or whitepapers. Ask: "Explain the interaction between the Databricks control plane and data plane." or "Describe the role of the Spark driver in a distributed application."
ChatGPT / Gemini: "Draw an analogy to explain Spark's distributed processing to someone new to big data." or "What are the advantages of using DataFrames over RDDs in PySpark for data engineering tasks?"


Study Tips:

Visualize: Draw diagrams of Spark's components (driver, executors) and how they interact.
Key Terms: Get comfortable with terms like "cluster manager," "worker node," "slots," "shuffling," etc.
Databricks Context: Understand how Databricks manages the underlying Spark infrastructure for you.



Day 4: Delta Lake Fundamentals & ACID Properties (3-4 hours)
[DBDEPC] Delta Lake Fundamentals & ACID Properties

Topic: Introduction to Delta Lake: open-source storage layer, Lakehouse architecture concept. ACID properties (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability) in Delta Lake.
Resource:

Official Docs: What is Delta Lake?
Official Docs: ACID transactions on Delta Lake
Databricks Blog: What is a Lakehouse?


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload Delta Lake whitepapers. Ask: "Explain how Delta Lake provides atomicity for transactions, even in a distributed environment." or "Summarize the key benefits of the Lakehouse architecture compared to traditional data lakes or data warehouses."
ChatGPT / Gemini: "Give a simple SQL example of how an UPDATE statement on a Delta table maintains ACID properties." or "Describe a scenario where Delta Lake's ACID properties prevent data corruption."


Study Tips:

Core Concepts: Understand that Delta Lake combines the best of data lakes (scalability, flexibility) and data warehouses (ACID, schema enforcement).
ACID Deep Dive: Focus on each ACID property and how Delta Lake guarantees it, especially in the context of concurrent operations.



Day 5: Delta Lake Time Travel & Schema Evolution (3-4 hours)
[DBDEPC] Delta Lake Time Travel & Schema Evolution

Topic: Delta Lake's capabilities: Time Travel (accessing historical versions of data), Schema Enforcement (preventing bad data inserts), and Schema Evolution (adapting schema to changes).
Resource:

Official Docs: Query an older version of a table (Time Travel)
Official Docs: Schema enforcement and evolution
Databricks Blog: Demystifying Delta Lake Schema Enforcement and Evolution


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload docs on Time Travel and Schema Evolution. Ask: "Provide PySpark code examples demonstrating how to use Delta Lake Time Travel to revert a table to a previous version." or "How does Delta Lake handle adding new columns to a table without breaking existing queries?"
ChatGPT / Gemini: "Describe a scenario where Delta Lake's Time Travel could save a data engineer from a critical data loss situation." or "What are the different modes for schema evolution in Delta Lake, and when would you use each?"


Study Tips:

Practical Scenarios: Think of real-world scenarios where these features would be invaluable (e.g., auditing, recovering from bad writes, handling evolving data sources).
Hands-on: If possible, try creating a Delta table, performing some operations, and then using Time Travel (VERSION AS OF, TIMESTAMP AS OF) and schema evolution (.option("mergeSchema", "true")).



Day 6: Databricks Workflows & Jobs (3-4 hours)
[DBDEPC] Databricks Workflows & Jobs

Topic: Automating data pipelines in Databricks using Databricks Jobs (scheduling, dependencies, retries). Introduction to Databricks Workflows for orchestrating multi-task pipelines.
Resource:

Official Docs: Introduction to Databricks Jobs
Official Docs: Create and run Databricks Jobs
Video: [suspicious link removed] (Search for a recent video on Databricks Workflows)


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload Databricks Jobs/Workflows docs. Ask: "Generate a YAML configuration for a Databricks Workflow that runs a Python notebook, followed by a Spark SQL task." or "Explain how to set up email notifications for job failures in Databricks."
ChatGPT / Gemini: "Describe a complex ETL pipeline that would benefit from orchestration using Databricks Workflows." or "What's the difference between a task and a job in Databricks Workflows?"


Study Tips:

Automation Focus: Understand that jobs and workflows are critical for moving from interactive development to production-ready automated pipelines.
Error Handling: Pay attention to how to configure job retries, timeouts, and notifications for robust operations.



Day 7: Databricks CLI, REST API & Basic Monitoring (3-4 hours)

Topic: Interacting with Databricks programmatically using the Databricks CLI (command-line interface) and Databricks REST API. Basic monitoring using Spark UI and Databricks UI.

ChatGPT / Gemini: "Explain how to programmatically restart a Databricks cluster using the REST API." or "What metrics should a data engineer monitor in the Spark UI to troubleshoot a slow-running job?"

Programmatic Control: Understand that CLI/API allows integration with CI/CD, custom scripts, and external orchestration tools.
Spark UI: Learn to navigate the Spark UI to inspect job performance (Stages, Tasks, Storage, Executors tabs). This is crucial for debugging.

Hierarchy: Pay close attention to the new 3-level namespace (catalog.schema.table) and how it differs from traditional Databricks workspaces.
Centralization: Understand that Unity Catalog brings traditional data warehouse governance capabilities to the data lake.

Fine-Grained Access: Understand the power of row-level and column-level security for sensitive data.

Day 10: Data Modeling - Medallion Architecture (3-4 hours)
[DBDEPC] Data Modeling - Medallion Architecture

Topic: Introduction to the Medallion Architecture (Bronze, Silver, Gold layers) for structuring data in a Lakehouse. Best practices for data ingestion and transformation across layers.
Resource:

Databricks Blog: The Delta Lakehouse: Medallion Architecture (Revisit this, focus on Medallion)
Official Docs: Medallion Architecture
Video: [suspicious link removed] (Search for a good explanation video)


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload Medallion Architecture whitepapers. Ask: "Describe the typical transformations that occur as data moves from the Bronze to the Silver layer in a Medallion architecture." or "Why is the Gold layer optimized for consumption by business intelligence tools and machine learning models?"
ChatGPT / Gemini: "Design a simple data pipeline using the Medallion architecture for ingesting web clickstream data." or "What are the benefits of maintaining distinct Bronze, Silver, and Gold layers in a data lakehouse?"


Study Tips:

Layer Purpose: Understand the distinct purpose and characteristics of each layer (Bronze: raw, Silver: cleansed/conformed, Gold: aggregated/feature-rich).
Incremental Processing: Think about how data would flow incrementally through these layers.



Day 11: Data Modeling - Schema Inference, Evolution & Constraints (3-4 hours)
[DBDEPC] Data Modeling - Schema Inference, Evolution & Constraints

Topic: Deep dive into Delta Lake's schema capabilities: automatic schema inference, explicit schema definition, schema evolution (add/drop columns), and basic constraints (NOT NULL, CHECK).
Resource:

Official Docs: Schema enforcement and evolution (Revisit this, focus on inference & constraints)
Databricks Blog: Delta Lake Table Constraints


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload Delta Lake schema docs. Ask: "Generate PySpark code to create a Delta table with an explicitly defined schema, including NOT NULL constraints." or "How does Delta Lake handle an incoming record that violates a schema constraint, and what are the options?"
ChatGPT / Gemini: "Describe a scenario where a data engineer would want to disable schema inference and define the schema explicitly." or "What's the difference between mergeSchema and overwriteSchema when handling schema evolution?"


Study Tips:

Data Quality: Understand how schema capabilities are crucial for maintaining data quality in the lakehouse.
Trade-offs: Weigh the convenience of schema inference against the control of explicit schema definition.



Day 12: Data Modeling - Efficient Updates & Merges (3-4 hours)
[DBDEPC] Data Modeling - Efficient Updates & Merges

Topic: Performing efficient UPDATE, DELETE, and MERGE operations on Delta tables. Understanding the MERGE INTO statement for UPSERT (update or insert) and its importance for handling changing data.
Resource:

Official Docs: Update, delete, and merge operations on Delta Lake tables
Databricks Blog: Simplify ETL with MERGE INTO


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload Delta Lake DML docs. Ask: "Provide a PySpark code example using MERGE INTO to handle both new records and updates in a batch ingestion process for a customer dimension table." or "Explain how MERGE INTO on Delta Lake ensures atomicity for complex ETL operations."
ChatGPT / Gemini: "Describe a situation where a simple INSERT OVERWRITE would be insufficient, and MERGE INTO would be necessary." or "How does Delta Lake optimize UPDATE and DELETE operations on large tables?"


Study Tips:

UPSERT Pattern: The MERGE INTO statement is incredibly powerful for ETL/ELT. Master its syntax and various conditional clauses.
Performance: Understand that Delta Lake optimizes these operations under the hood, making them efficient even on large datasets.



Day 13: Python OOP, Decorators & Generators for DE (3-4 hours)

ChatGPT / Gemini: "Provide a simple Python generator function that yields lines from a large file without loading the entire file into memory." or "When would using a decorator be more appropriate than directly modifying a function's code?"

Modularity: OOP helps in organizing complex data pipelines into manageable, testable units.
Efficiency: Generators are crucial for memory efficiency when dealing with large datasets; decorators help with cross-cutting concerns (logging, authentication) without modifying core logic.



Day 14: Python Error Handling & Context Managers (3-4 hours)
[DBDEPC] Python Error Handling & Context Managers

Topic: Robust Error Handling (try-except-finally) in Python for data pipelines. Using with statements for Context Managers (e.g., file handling, database connections).
Resource:

Free Course: Python Exception Handling Tutorial (DataCamp blog)

AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload docs on error handling. Ask: "Generate a Python function that attempts to open a file, reads data, handles FileNotFoundError and PermissionError, and ensures the file is always closed."
ChatGPT / Gemini: "Explain how a custom context manager could simplify managing a SparkSession in a local testing environment." or "Provide a try-except block for a PySpark operation that handles potential data type conversion errors."
Microsoft Copilot: Type try: or with open( and Copilot will often suggest the appropriate except or context manager structure.


Study Tips:

Hands-on: Practice writing Python scripts that simulate common data engineering errors (e.g., trying to open a non-existent file, dividing by zero, type mismatch). Then implement robust try-except blocks to handle them gracefully.
Resource Management: Understand the critical importance of with statements for ensuring resources (files, database connections, locks) are properly released, even if errors occur. This prevents resource leaks and improves pipeline stability.

Core Concept: Optimistic concurrency is fundamental to Delta Lake's reliability in a multi-user environment. Understand its mechanics and benefits.

Day 29: Structured Streaming Fundamentals & DLT Introduction (3-4 hours)
Structured Streaming Fundamentals & DLT Introduction

Topic: Introduction to Apache Spark Structured Streaming: micro-batch processing, continuous processing, sources, sinks, triggers. Overview of Delta Live Tables (DLT) as a managed framework for building reliable streaming ETL.
Resource:

Official Databricks Docs: What is Spark Structured Streaming? (Read introduction and basic concepts)
Official Databricks Docs: What is Delta Live Tables? (Read introduction and key benefits)
Video Tutorial: [suspicious link removed] (Search for a recent concise explanation)


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload Structured Streaming and DLT documentation. Ask: "Compare the developer experience of building streaming pipelines with raw Structured Streaming versus Delta Live Tables." or "What are the common challenges in real-time data ingestion that Structured Streaming helps solve?"
ChatGPT / Gemini: "Write a simple PySpark Structured Streaming code to read from a file source, apply a transformation, and write to a Delta Lake sink." or "Explain the concept of 'end-to-end exactly-once' processing in Structured Streaming."


Study Tips:

Micro-Batching: Understand the micro-batch processing model and how it simulates continuous processing.
DLT's Abstraction: Recognize that DLT builds on Structured Streaming, simplifying pipeline orchestration, error handling, and monitoring.



Day 30: Stream-Stream Joins & Watermarking (3-4 hours)
Stream-Stream Joins & Watermarking

Topic: Advanced Structured Streaming concepts: performing joins between two streaming DataFrames, and the crucial role of watermarking to manage state and enable time-based aggregations/joins in streaming data.
Resource:

Official Databricks Docs: Stream-stream joins in Structured Streaming
Official Databricks Docs: Watermarking in Structured Streaming
Blog/Article: [Understanding Watermarking in Apache Spark Structured Streaming](https://www.google.com/search?q=https://databricks.com/blog/2017/04/26/processing-data- deduplication-apache-spark-structured-streaming.html)


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload stream-stream joins and watermarking docs. Ask: "Provide a PySpark Structured Streaming example for joining a stream of clicks with a stream of user profiles using watermarking." or "How does watermarking help prevent unbounded state growth in streaming aggregations?"
ChatGPT / Gemini: "Design a Structured Streaming pipeline that joins real-time order events with product inventory updates, ensuring late-arriving events are handled." or "Explain the concept of 'event time' versus 'processing time' in streaming with respect to watermarking."


Study Tips:

Hands-on: Watermarking is a bit abstract until you see it in action. Try to build a simple streaming pipeline with a windowed aggregation or a stream-stream join and experiment with different watermark durations.
State Management: Understand that joins and aggregations in streaming require state management, and watermarking is key to managing this state efficiently.



Day 31: Change Data Capture (CDC) with Delta Live Tables (3-4 hours)
Change Data Capture (CDC) with Delta Live Tables

Topic: Implementing Change Data Capture (CDC) patterns using Delta Live Tables (DLT) for replicating database changes or synchronizing data with a lakehouse. Understanding the APPLY CHANGES INTO DLT syntax.
Resource:

Official Databricks Docs: Simplify change data capture (CDC) with APPLY CHANGES INTO
Databricks Blog: Simplify CDC with Delta Live Tables
Video Tutorial: [suspicious link removed] (Search for a recent DLT CDC demo)


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload DLT CDC docs. Ask: "Generate a DLT Python pipeline that uses APPLY CHANGES INTO to sync a stream of customer updates (inserts, updates, deletes) into a target Delta table, handling Type 1 SCD." or "Explain the prerequisites for using APPLY CHANGES INTO in DLT."
ChatGPT / Gemini: "Describe a real-world scenario where APPLY CHANGES INTO would be a more efficient solution than a traditional MERGE INTO statement for CDC." or "How does DLT's APPLY CHANGES INTO handle out-of-order records in a CDC stream?"


Study Tips:

DLT's Power: Recognize how DLT's APPLY CHANGES INTO simplifies complex CDC logic that would typically require intricate MERGE INTO statements and custom logic.
Source Data: Understand the requirements for source data when using CDC (e.g., presence of operation types, unique keys).



Day 32: Advanced Spark Optimization (Caching, Shuffle, Tungsten) (3-4 hours)
Advanced Spark Optimization (Caching, Shuffle, Tungsten)

Topic: Deeper dive into Spark performance tuning: caching (persist levels, storage levels), understanding shuffle operations and their cost, Catalyst Optimizer and Project Tungsten. Spark configurations for performance.
Resource:

Official Databricks Docs: Apache Spark performance tuning
Article: Spark Caching Best Practices (Focus on DataFrame/Dataset caching too)
Blog: Understanding Spark Shuffle


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload advanced Spark optimization docs. Ask: "When should I use .cache() vs .persist(StorageLevel.MEMORY_AND_DISK) in PySpark, and what's the difference?" or "Explain how Project Tungsten improves Spark's memory and CPU efficiency."
ChatGPT / Gemini: "Given a Spark job with high shuffle spill, what are the common causes and potential solutions (code and config adjustments)?" or "How does the Catalyst Optimizer transform a logical plan into an optimized physical plan?"


Study Tips:

Spark UI (Again!): Continually use the Spark UI to diagnose performance bottlenecks related to shuffle, caching, and data skew. It's your primary diagnostic tool.
Experimentation: Change Spark configurations, try different persist levels, or reorder operations in your code to see the impact on job performance and resource utilization.



Day 33: User-Defined Functions (UDFs) & Catalyst Optimizer (3-4 hours)
User-Defined Functions (UDFs) & Catalyst Optimizer

Topic: Creating and using PySpark/Scala UDFs. Understanding their performance implications (serialization, Python overhead). Introduction to Spark's Catalyst Optimizer (logical plan, physical plan, optimization rules, code generation).
Resource:

Official Databricks Docs: User-defined functions (UDFs)
Article: Deep Dive into Spark Catalyst Optimizer (Focus on Catalyst part)
Video: [suspicious link removed] (Search for good UDF best practices)


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload UDF and Catalyst docs. Ask: "Provide a PySpark example of a vectorized UDF and explain why it's more performant than a traditional UDF." or "How does the Catalyst Optimizer rewrite a SQL query for better execution?"
ChatGPT / Gemini: "When should I avoid using UDFs in Spark, and what are the alternatives?" or "Explain the difference between a logical plan and a physical plan in Spark's Catalyst Optimizer."


Study Tips:

Performance Trade-offs: UDFs can be powerful but often introduce performance bottlenecks. Understand when to use them and when to seek native Spark functions.
Query Plans: Learn to interpret explain() plans in Spark to see how Catalyst optimizes your queries and where UDFs might impact performance.



Day 34: Integrating Databricks with Message Queues (Kafka, Azure Event Hubs, AWS Kinesis) (3-4 hours)
Integrating Databricks with Message Queues (Kafka, Azure Event Hubs, AWS Kinesis)

Topic: Reading and writing streaming data from/to popular message queues (Apache Kafka, Azure Event Hubs, AWS Kinesis) using Spark Structured Streaming. Understanding connection configurations and common patterns.
Resource:

Official Databricks Docs: Connect to Apache Kafka
Official Databricks Docs: Connect to Azure Event Hubs
Official Databricks Docs: Connect to AWS Kinesis


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload message queue integration docs. Ask: "Generate a PySpark Structured Streaming code snippet to read JSON messages from an Azure Event Hub and write them to a Delta table." or "What are the common authentication methods when connecting Databricks to Kafka?"
ChatGPT / Gemini: "Design a real-time data ingestion pipeline from IoT devices using AWS Kinesis, Databricks, and Delta Lake." or "How do Spark Structured Streaming offsets work when consuming from Kafka?"


Study Tips:

Conceptual Flow: Understand the end-to-end data flow: device/application -> message queue -> Databricks Structured Streaming -> Delta Lake.
Cloud-Specifics: While the Spark code is similar, pay attention to the cloud-specific configurations (connection strings, authentication, topic names) for each message queue service.



Day 35: DSA - Advanced Topics (Dynamic Programming, Backtracking Introduction) (2-3 hours)
[DBDEPC] Data Structures & Algorithms (DSA) - Advanced Topics (Dynamic Programming, Backtracking Introduction)

Topic: Introduction to Dynamic Programming (memoization, tabulation). Introduction to Backtracking algorithms (e.g., N-Queens problem, Sudoku solver). Continued practice.

Microsoft Copilot: When attempting DP or Backtracking problems, Copilot can assist with the recursive structure, memoization dictionaries, or base cases.


Study Tips:

Identify Patterns: For DP, the challenge is recognizing when a problem can be solved with DP (overlapping subproblems, optimal substructure).
Recursive Thinking: Backtracking is fundamentally recursive. Master recursion first.
Consistency: Keep up the consistent DSA practice. These advanced topics require significant mental effort and repeated exposure.

Phase 0: Immediate Impact & Quick Wins
Approx. Time Commitment: 1-2 focused days (8-16 hours total, ideally over a weekend or 2-3 evenings).
Purpose: Address immediate management expectations, demonstrate proactivity, and gain practical experience with AI tools.

Week 1: Immediate Impact & Databricks Foundations
Day 1: AI Essentials & Prompt Engineering Basics (4-5 hours)
AI Essentials & Prompt Engineering Basics

Topic: Introduction to AI, ML, Gen AI concepts. Foundational Prompt Engineering principles.
Resource:

Course: Google AI Essentials Course (Coursera, Free Audit/Financial Aid available)
Article: Prompt Engineering Guide - Free and Open Source (Basic techniques section)


AI Tool & Tips:

ChatGPT / Gemini (LLMs): Use them as an interactive tutor. After reading a concept (e.g., "What is a Transformer model?"), ask the AI: "Explain [concept] like I'm 5," then "Explain it to a data engineer." Follow up with "Give me 3 real-world use cases for [concept] in data engineering."
Microsoft Copilot: Use Copilot for brainstorming. Ask "Suggest 5 ways generative AI can help a data engineer improve ETL processes" or "What common errors can occur when writing SQL for Spark, and how can Copilot help debug them?"


Study Tips:

Without NotebookLM: Actively take notes in your preferred format. After studying a concept, try to explain it in your own words or draw a simple diagram. Use flashcards for key terms.
With NotebookLM: If you have access, upload the course transcripts or key articles into NotebookLM. Use its summarization feature to quickly grasp main ideas and ask follow-up questions directly on the content to deepen your understanding.



Day 2: Practical Prompt Engineering & Immediate Application (4-5 hours)
Practical Prompt Engineering & Immediate Application

Topic: Advanced Prompt Engineering for code generation, debugging, documentation, brainstorming.
Resource:

Article: OpenAI's Prompt Engineering Best Practices (Focus on techniques like few-shot learning, chain-of-thought).
Hands-on: Practice using an LLM of choice (ChatGPT/Gemini/Copilot) for your actual work tasks.


AI Tool & Tips:

ChatGPT / Gemini (LLMs):

Code Generation/Debugging: When facing a SQL or Python coding problem, paste your code and the error message. Ask, "What's wrong with this SQL query? Provide a corrected version and explain the fix." or "Debug this Python script and tell me why it failed."
Documentation: Paste a block of your existing code and ask, "Generate detailed documentation for this Python function, including parameters, return values, and a brief example." or "Summarize this SQL query's purpose and logic in 3 bullet points."
Brainstorming: "I need to design a data pipeline to ingest sensor data from IoT devices. What are 5 potential challenges and how can Databricks address them?"


NotebookLM:

Tip (Without NotebookLM): If you don't have NotebookLM, manually copy and paste key parts of long documentation or articles into your LLM of choice and ask it to summarize, extract key terms, or answer specific questions about the content.
Tip (With NotebookLM): Upload Databricks documentation PDFs or long articles. Ask it to "Summarize the key differences between managed and external Delta tables," "Extract all Spark SQL performance optimization tips," or "Generate flashcards on Delta Lake ACID properties." NotebookLM can synthesize information across multiple uploaded documents.




Study Tips:

General: The best way to learn prompt engineering is by doing. Experiment with different phrasing and observe how the AI's response changes. Always start with a clear, specific prompt, and then iterate.
Active Learning: Try to predict what the AI will generate before it does, then compare your prediction to the actual output. This helps build intuition.




Phase 1: AI-Focused Databricks Deep Dive & Data Engineering Excellence
Approx. Time Commitment: 4-6 Months (10-15 hours/week).
Purpose: Master a leading AI-enabled data platform, formalize your expertise, and build production-grade data pipelines specifically for AI. Establish a strong base for AI and maintain foundational CS skill development.

Week 1 (cont.)
Day 3: Databricks Architecture & Apache Spark Fundamentals (3-4 hours)
[DBDEPC] Databricks Architecture & Apache Spark Fundamentals](https://www.google.com/search?q=%23databricks-architecture--apache-spark-fundamentals)

Topic: Databricks Architecture (Control Plane, Data Plane, Workspace). Apache Spark Core Concepts (RDDs, DataFrames, SparkSession, transformations, actions).
Resource:

[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Docs: Databricks Architecture Overview
[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Docs: Apache Spark Overview
Free Course: Spark 3.x - Basics to Advanced with Python (PySpark) (YouTube playlist, selected foundational videos)


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload the Databricks architecture documentation and Spark overview. Ask: "What is the role of the Driver Node vs. Worker Nodes in Spark execution?" or "Explain the concept of lazy evaluation in Spark with a simple Python example."
ChatGPT / Gemini: Practice writing simple Spark DataFrame transformations. "Write a PySpark code to read a CSV, filter rows where 'age' > 30, and select 'name' and 'city' columns." Then, ask: "Explain the lineage (DAG) for this Spark DataFrame operation."
Microsoft Copilot (VS Code Integration): As you write PySpark code in VS Code, let Copilot suggest methods (.filter(), .select(), .withColumn()). If you're stuck, type a comment like # read csv and filter by condition and see its suggestions.


Study Tips:

Hands-on: The best way to understand Spark is to run code. Use Databricks Community Edition or a free Databricks trial to execute the examples from the documentation.
Conceptual Depth: Focus not just on how to write Spark code, but why certain operations are performed (e.g., transformations vs. actions, lazy evaluation).



Day 4: Delta Lake Fundamentals & ACID Properties (3-4 hours)
[DBDEPC] Delta Lake Fundamentals & ACID Properties](https://www.google.com/search?q=%23delta-lake-fundamentals--acid-properties)

Topic: Delta Lake core concepts, transaction log, ACID properties (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability).
Resource:

[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Docs: What is Delta Lake?
[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Docs: Delta Lake ACID Guarantees
Article: Understanding Delta Lake ACID Properties (Datacamp blog)


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload Delta Lake documentation. Ask for "Examples of how Delta Lake handles concurrent writes" or "Compare and contrast Delta Lake with traditional data lakes regarding data reliability."
ChatGPT / Gemini: Ask: "Explain a scenario where Delta Lake's Atomicity prevents data corruption in an ETL pipeline." or "Give me a simple PySpark Delta Lake code snippet to create a table and perform an INSERT OVERWRITE operation, then explain its implications for ACID properties."


Study Tips:

Visual learners: Search for "Delta Lake ACID properties animation" on YouTube to find visual explanations. They can make abstract concepts much clearer.
Scenario-based learning: Think of real-world data problems (e.g., concurrent writes, schema changes) and how Delta Lake's features (like ACID) solve them.



Day 5: Delta Lake Time Travel & Schema Evolution (3-4 hours)
[DBDEPC] Delta Lake Time Travel & Schema Evolution](https://www.google.com/search?q=%23delta-lake-time-travel--schema-evolution)

Topic: Delta Lake features: Time Travel (versioning), Schema Enforcement, Schema Evolution, VACUUM, OPTIMIZE.
Resource:

[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Docs: Query an older version of a Delta Lake table (Time Travel)
[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Docs: Schema enforcement and evolution
Article: Delta Lake OPTIMIZE and VACUUM Explained


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload documentation on Time Travel and Schema Evolution. Ask: "How can I revert a Delta table to a specific version using Python and SQL?" or "What are the common strategies for handling schema changes in a Delta Lake table?"
ChatGPT / Gemini: Role-play a scenario: "You are a data engineer. A new column was added to the source data that broke a downstream dashboard. How would you use Delta Lake Time Travel and Schema Evolution features to fix this problem and prevent it in the future?"
Microsoft Copilot: While writing Delta Lake operations in a notebook, try commenting: # use time travel to query data from yesterday or # add new column to existing delta table allowing schema evolution and see its suggestions for syntax.


Study Tips:

Practical Application: Create a Delta table, insert data, make changes, then use Time Travel to query previous versions. Experiment with mergeSchema and overwriteSchema to see their effects. Hands-on is crucial here.
"Why" questions: Always ask yourself why a particular feature (like Time Travel) is useful in a production data pipeline.



Day 6: Databricks Workflows & Jobs (3-4 hours)
[DBDEPC] Databricks Workflows & Jobs](https://www.google.com/search?q=%23databricks-workflows--jobs)

Topic: Orchestrating tasks with Databricks Jobs (single-task, multi-task, dependencies), scheduling, retries, alerts.
Resource:

[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Docs: What are Databricks Jobs?
[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Docs: Create and run Databricks Jobs
Free Tutorial (YouTube): Databricks Workflows & Jobs Tutorial (Search for more recent ones if available, e.g., from Databricks' channel)


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload documentation on Databricks Jobs. Ask: "Generate a checklist for setting up a production-ready Databricks job, including best practices for error handling and alerting."
ChatGPT / Gemini: "Describe a scenario where a multi-task job with sequential dependencies would be more efficient than multiple single-task jobs in Databricks." Or "Given a job that fails frequently, what are the key configurations I should check (retries, cluster config, logging) and why?"


Study Tips:

UI Exploration: Spend time in the Databricks Workspace UI creating and configuring different types of jobs. Observe how dependencies are set up and how job runs are displayed.
Error Simulation: Try creating a job that will intentionally fail (e.g., bad code, missing table) and observe how Databricks handles errors and how you would diagnose them.



Day 7: Databricks CLI, REST API & Basic Monitoring (3-4 hours)
[DBDEPC] Databricks CLI, REST API & Basic Monitoring](https://www.google.com/search?q=%23databricks-cli-rest-api--basic-monitoring)

Topic: Interacting with Databricks programmatically via CLI and REST API. Basic job monitoring and interpreting Spark UI for performance.
Resource:

[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Docs: What is the Databricks CLI?
[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Docs: Databricks REST API overview (Focus on Jobs API, Clusters API)
[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Docs: Monitoring and logging on Databricks (Read basic sections on job run details and Spark UI overview)
Article: Understanding Spark UI for Performance Tuning (Focus on key tabs like Jobs, Stages, Tasks)


AI Tool & Tips:

ChatGPT / Gemini:

CLI/API: "Generate a Databricks CLI command to list all jobs in my workspace." or "Show me a Python requests example to trigger a Databricks job run via the REST API."
Monitoring: "When looking at the Spark UI, what are the top 3 metrics to check first if a job is running slowly, and what do they indicate?"


Microsoft Copilot: If you're working on a script to interact with Databricks, type a comment like # use databricks cli to create a new cluster and see if Copilot can suggest the command structure.


Study Tips:

Hands-on CLI/API: Install the Databricks CLI and try basic commands. Authenticate and try listing clusters or jobs. Use Postman or Python's requests library to make a few REST API calls.
Spark UI Exploration: Run some Spark jobs (even simple ones) on Databricks and actively explore the Spark UI. Click through the tabs (Jobs, Stages, Tasks, Storage, Environment) to familiarize yourself with the metrics. This will be invaluable for the certification.



Week 2: Unity Catalog & Advanced Delta Lake
Day 8: Unity Catalog Fundamentals (3-4 hours)
[DBDEPC] Unity Catalog Fundamentals](https://www.google.com/search?q=%23unity-catalog-fundamentals)

Topic: Introduction to Unity Catalog (UC): unified governance for data & AI assets, metastore, three-level namespace, managed vs. external tables in UC context.
Resource:

[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Docs: What is Unity Catalog?
[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Docs: Understand Unity Catalog managed tables
[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Docs: Understand Unity Catalog external tables


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload UC docs. Ask: "Summarize the benefits of Unity Catalog over traditional Databricks metastores." or "Create a comparison table: Unity Catalog managed table vs. external table."
ChatGPT / Gemini: "Explain the three-level namespace (catalog.schema.table) in Unity Catalog with a practical example." or "Describe a use case where an external table in Unity Catalog would be preferred over a managed table."


Study Tips:

Conceptual Clarity: Unity Catalog is central to modern Databricks. Focus on understanding the why behind its design (governance, centralization, simplicity) in addition to the how.
Comparison: Mentally (or with a whiteboard) compare Unity Catalog's approach to how you've handled permissions and metadata in previous data environments.



Day 9: Unity Catalog Security & Governance (3-4 hours)
[DBDEPC] Unity Catalog Security & Governance](https://www.google.com/search?q=%23unity-catalog-security--governance)

Topic: Fine-grained access controls (grants, revokes), row-level security (RLS), column-level security (CLS) / data masking in Unity Catalog. Managing object privileges.
Resource:

[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Docs: Manage Unity Catalog privileges
[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Docs: Filter and mask sensitive data using row filters and column masks


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload the access control and RLS/CLS docs. Ask: "Provide SQL examples for granting SELECT privilege on a specific column to a user group in Unity Catalog." or "Generate a scenario where row-level security is critical for data privacy, and show the implementation steps."
ChatGPT / Gemini: "Explain the difference between GRANT SELECT ON TABLE and GRANT SELECT ON COLUMN in Unity Catalog." Or "How does data masking work in Unity Catalog to protect sensitive information?"
Microsoft Copilot: When writing GRANT statements in a Databricks SQL notebook, type a comment like # grant select on table to user and let Copilot auto-complete the syntax.


Study Tips:

Practical Permissions: If possible, practice setting up users, groups, and granting/revoking permissions in a Databricks workspace with Unity Catalog enabled. Observe the effects of different privilege levels.
Data Protection Mindset: Think about real-world sensitive data and how RLS/CLS would be applied to protect it from different user roles.



Day 10: Data Modeling - Medallion Architecture (3-4 hours)
[DBDEPC] Data Modeling - Medallion Architecture](https://www.google.com/search?q=%23data-modeling---medallion-architecture)

Topic: Medallion Architecture (Bronze, Silver, Gold layers) for Lakehouse. Objective of data transformations at each stage.
Resource:

[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Blog: What is the medallion lakehouse architecture?
Article: Implementing Medallion Architecture on Databricks


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload articles on Medallion Architecture. Ask: "What are the common data quality checks performed when promoting data from Bronze to Silver layer?" or "Design a simple Medallion Architecture for customer sales data, listing typical transformations at each stage."
ChatGPT / Gemini: "Explain the purpose of the Gold layer in Medallion Architecture and provide 3 examples of data products found there." Or "Describe how schema enforcement and evolution fit into the Medallion Architecture."


Study Tips:

Conceptual Framework: The Medallion Architecture is a conceptual framework. Understand its principles and how it helps organize data quality, reusability, and governance in a data lakehouse.
Design Exercise: For any new dataset you encounter, try to map out how it would flow through Bronze, Silver, and Gold layers.



Day 11: Data Modeling - Schema Inference, Evolution & Constraints (3-4 hours)
[DBDEPC] Data Modeling - Schema Inference, Evolution & Constraints](https://www.google.com/search?q=%23data-modeling---schema-inference-evolution--constraints)

Topic: Deep dive into Delta Lake's schema inference, schema evolution (mergeSchema, overwriteSchema), and applying NOT NULL constraints in Unity Catalog.
Resource:

[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Docs: Schema inference and evolution
[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Docs: Constraints on Databricks (Focus on NOT NULL for now)


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload docs. Ask: "Provide code examples (PySpark & SQL) for using mergeSchema and overwriteSchema when writing to a Delta table, and explain when to use each."
ChatGPT / Gemini: "What are the risks of using overwriteSchema without careful consideration?" or "How can NOT NULL constraints in Unity Catalog improve data quality in a Bronze layer table?"


Study Tips:

Experimentation: Create a Delta table, write data with a simple schema. Then try writing data with new columns or changed data types. Observe how Delta Lake behaves with and without mergeSchema or overwriteSchema.
Data Integrity: Understand how constraints (even basic NOT NULL) contribute to data quality and reliability, especially important for certification.



Day 12: Data Modeling - Efficient Updates & Merges (3-4 hours)
[DBDEPC] Data Modeling - Efficient Updates & Merges](https://www.google.com/search?q=%23data-modeling---efficient-updates--merges)

Topic: Performing efficient MERGE INTO operations (upserts) for SCD Type 1, and managing data changes in Delta Lake.
Resource:

[DBDEPC] Official Databricks Docs: Perform upserts using mergeInto
Article: Slowly Changing Dimensions (SCD) Type 1 vs Type 2 with Delta Lake (Focus on Type 1 for this day)


AI Tool & Tips:

NotebookLM: Upload docs/articles on MERGE INTO. Ask: "Outline the steps to implement an SCD Type 1 update using MERGE INTO in PySpark for customer data."
ChatGPT / Gemini: "Compare INSERT OVERWRITE vs. MERGE INTO for updating a Delta table. When would you choose one over the other?"
Microsoft Copilot: When writing a MERGE INTO statement, let Copilot help with the WHEN MATCHED and WHEN NOT MATCHED clauses.


Study Tips:

Practical Scenarios: Think of datasets where you'd need to update existing records or insert new ones based on a source. Practice writing MERGE INTO statements for these scenarios.
Performance: Understand that MERGE INTO is optimized for changes, and be aware of its performance implications on large datasets.



Day 13: Python OOP, Decorators & Generators for DE (3-4 hours)
[DBDEPC] Python OOP, Decorators & Generators for DE](https://www.google.com/search?q=%23python-oop-decorators--generators-for-de)

Topic: Practical Object-Oriented Programming (Classes, Objects, Inheritance) in Python for structuring data engineering code. Using Decorators to enhance functions (e.g., logging, timing). Generators and Iterators for memory-efficient data processing.
